newsitem.title: USA: Belize PM sees free trade pact after banana row.
newsitem.headline: Belize PM sees free trade pact after banana row.

text.p: Belize Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel on Monday said he supported the EU banana regime that favored Carribean nations, but added that eliminating the system might lead to better trade integration.

The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled last month that the EU's import regime, which allows banana growers in the Carribean, Surinam and Belize preferential access to European markets, violated global trade accords.
Speaking at the Americas Society here, Esquivel said his country joined the Carribean in the EU appeal of the ruling.
"We certainly feel there are grounds for an appeal and we would support that appeal," Esquivel said.
He added, however, that the WTO decision might resolve the bitter dispute, and bolster prospects for wider free trade accords in Central America and the Carribean.

"In a way the WTO intervention may actually help in so far as it will decide once and for all what the provisions will be," Esquivel said. "Presumably everyone will have to accept that one way or the other."
"That might make the (free trade) negotiations a little bit easier," he said, adding that "I think the countries would rather not deal with that issue until they have to."
He said Belize recognized the global economy was moving away from preferential agreements and toward free trade.
The prime minister also forecast that Belize would witness GDP growth of 3.5 to 4.0 percent in 1997 and inflation would drop to around 4.0 percent from around 6.0 percent last year.
